foot after losing his leg in a water
skiing accident over 30 years ago van
Phillips set out to revolutionize the
field of prosthetic design he was
uniquely qualified it's a symbiotic
relation between the ground in your head
you have to know what it will feel like
before you can design the next part of
it when you land on something that's
like a crutch it's going to feel like a
crutch when you land on something it has
a bendable or an energy absorbent member
it's going to spring with you oh okay in
1984 Phillips designed the first carbon
graphite foot instead of mimicking human
bone structure he used a curve design to
increase shock absorption and energy
storage nine years later he created a
new design taking a cue from nature we
developed a foot that was actually very
similar to the shape of a cheetah it's a
great big sea so we emulated that in the
machida foot or archita foot with carbon
graphite the new shape increased push
off and spring if you were to take our
microscope and dissect this flex foot
what you would see is thousands if maybe
not a million carbon graphite strands
very very like almost like dental floss
the strands simulate the function of a
cheetah's tendons and ligaments carbon
graphite is actually even more efficient
than the ligaments in the Tuda it's
actually concerned return more energy in
the de tu de the foots effectiveness
sparked controversy this year when
sprinter oscar pistorius was initially
barred from the olympics after officials
said his cheetah feet were more
efficient than human feet the decision
was reversed and Pistorius is trying to
attain an
qualifying time in the meantime the man
behind the feet hopes to use them for
global good what I'm currently spending
the rest of my prosthetic career on it
at least at this point it seems is
developing a foot for landmine survivors
I know what those amputees have to wear
